lines.text: [Don Lockwood is being mobbed by several fans on the street]

[desperately]
Hey, Cos! Do something! Call me a cab!
OK, you're a cab.

[unimpressed]
Thanks a lot!
[after filming a love scene]
Oh Donny! You couldn't kiss me like that and not mean it just a teensy bit!
Meet the greatest actor in the world! I'd rather kiss a tarantula.
You don't mean that.
I don't - - Hey Joe, get me a tarantula.
Gee, this wig weighs a ton! What dope'd wear a thing like this?
Everybody used to wear them, Lina.
Well, then everybody was a dope.
Lina. She can't act, she can't sing, she can't dance. A triple threat.
What's wrong with the way I talk? What's the big idea? Am I dumb or something?
Talking pictures, that means I'm out of a job. At last I can start suffering and write that symphony.
You're not out of job, we're putting you in as head of our new music department.
Oh, thanks, R.F.! At last I can stop suffering and write that symphony.
Short people have long faces, and long people have short faces. Big people have little humor, and little people have no humor at all.
Lina, you're a beautiful woman. Audiences think you've got a voice to match. The studio's gotta keep their stars from looking ridiculous at any cost.
Nobody's got that much money.
Moses supposes his toeses are roses, but Moses supposes erroneously. Moses he knowses his toeses aren't roses as Moses supposes his toeses to be.

[picks up a cake]
Here's one thing I learned from the movies!
[Throws it at Don but hits Lina]
Make 'em laugh!
If we bring a little joy into your humdrum lives, it makes us feel as though our hard work ain't been in vain for nothin'. Bless you all.
[filming a scene with a microphone hidden in a bush]
Lina! We're missing every other word! You've got to talk into the mike!

[pointing at the bush]
Well, I can't make love to a bush!
they talk!"

[with a voice to peel paint]
Well of *course* we talk. Don't everybody?
What do they think I am? Dumb or something? Why, I make more money than - than - than Calvin Coolidge! Put together!
Now look, Miss Lamont, Don and I...
Don? Don't you *dare* call him Don! I was calling him Don before you were born! I mean... You-you were kissing him!
*I* was kissing *her*! I happen to be in love with her.
That's ridiculous. Everybody knows you're in love with me.
What's your lofty mission in life that lets you sneer at my humble profession?
I'm an actress...
Oh...
...on the stage.
Oh, on the stage, well I'd like to see you act, what are you in right now? I could brush up on my English, or bring along an interpreter, that is if they'd let in a *movie* actor.
I'm not in a play right now, but I will be. I'm going to New York...
Oh, you're going to New York and then some day we'll all hear of you, won't we? Kathy Selden as Juliet, as Lady Macbeth, as King Lear. You'll have to wear a beard for that one of course.
Laugh all you want, but at least the stage is a dignified profession.

[scoffing]
Dignified profession.
What do you have to be so conceited about? You're nothing but a shadow on film... just a shadow. You're not flesh and blood.
Oh, no?
[moves amorously towards her]
Stop!
What can I do to you, I'm only a shadow.

[giving Lina diction lessons]
Repeat after me - Tah, Tey, Tee, Toe, Too.
Tah, Tey, Tye, Tow, Tyo.
No, no, no Miss Lamont, Round tones, round tones. Now, let me hear you read your line.
And I cayn't stand'im.
And I can't stand him.
And I cayn't stand'im.
Can't.
Cayn't.
Caaaan't
Cayyyyn't
Gee, I'm glad you turned up, we've been looking inside every cake in town.

[while filming a love scene]
Why, you rattlesnake! You got that poor kid fired.
That's not all I'm gonna do if I ever get my hands on her.
I never heard of anything so low. Why did you do it?
Because you liked her. I could tell.
So that's it. Believe me, I don't like her half as much as I hate you, you reptile.
Sticks and stones may break my bones...
I'd like to break every bone in your body.
You and who else, you big lummox?
Why bother to shoot this film? Why not release the old one under a new title? You've seen one, you've seen them all.
Hey, what'd you say that for?
What's the matter?
That's what that Kathy Selden said to me that night.
That's three weeks ago, you still thinking about that?
I can't get her out of my mind.
How could you - she's the first dame who hasn't fallen for your line since you were four.
"People"? I ain't "people." I am a - "a shimmering, glowing star in the cinema firmament."
[picks up newspaper]
It says so - right here.
there is nothing between us. There has never been anything between us. Just air.
Oh, Donny, you don't mean that.
Are you sure it's all right? Being seen with me?
You mean lofty star with humble player?
Not exactly, but for lunch don't you usually tear a pheasant with Miss Lamont?
Kathy, all the stories about Lina and me are sheer publicity.
Oh? It certainly seems more than that. From all those columns in the newspapers and articles in the fan magazines...
You read the fan magazines?
I pick them up at the beauty parlor or the dentist's office, just like anybody.
Really?
Well... I buy four or five a month.
Four or five...
But anyway, to get back to the point, you and Miss Lamont do achieve a certain intimacy in all your pictures...
Did you say *all* our pictures?
I guess if I think about it I've seen eight or nine of them.
You know I remember someone saying, "If you've seen one you've seen 'em all".
I said some awful things that night, didn't I?
No. I deserved them. But I must admit I was hurt by them. So hurt in fact that I haven't been able to think about anything but you ever since.
I'm no actor. I never was. Just a bunch of dumb show. I know that now.
Well, at least you're taking it lying down.
No. No kidding, Cosmo. Did you ever see anything as ridiculous as me on that screen tonight?
Yeah, how about Lina?
All right. I ran her a close second. Maybe it was a photo finish. I'm through, fellas.
Don, you're not through!
Why of course not. Why, with your looks and figure, you could drive an ice wagon or shine shoes!
Block hats!
Sell pencils!
Dig ditches!
Or worse still, go back to vaudeville.
What's the first thing an actor learns? "The show must go on!' Come rain, come shine, come snow, come sleet, the show MUST go on!
I just had to tell you how good you were.
Excuse me.
No, no, don't go.
[pointing to cake she came out of at beginning of scene]
Now that I know where you live I'd like to see you home.
[after Lina gets a pie thrown in her face]
Lina, You've never looked lovelier.
[after Don shows up late for a party]
Don, how did you come, by way of Australia?
Tell me the truth, am I a good actor?
As long as I'm working for Monumental Pictures, you're the greatest of 'em all.
Dignity. Always, dignity.
Well, we movie stars get the glory. I guess we have to take the little heartaches that go with it. People think we lead lives of glamour and romance, but we're really lonely - terribly lonely.
Lina, you were gorgeous!
Yeah, Lina, you looked pretty good for a girl.
[after the demonstration of a talking picture]
What do you think of it, Dexter?
It'll never amount to a thing.

[with heavy, snotty accent]
Its vulgar!
That's what they said about the horseless carriage.
[after Cosmo's car breaks down]
Don't tell me, it's a flat tire.
I can't undertand it. This car hasn't given me a lick of trouble in nearly 6 hours.
[last lines]
Ladies and gentlemen, stop that girl, that girl running up the aisle. Stop her! That's the girl whose voice you heard and loved tonight. She's the real star of the picture. Kathy Selden!
[theater audience applauds and cheers]
Kathy...
[Don and Kathy sing "You Are My Lucky Star"]
Which of my pictures have you seen?
I don't remember. I saw one once.
You saw one once?
Yes, I think you were dueling and there was a girl - Lina Lamont. But I don't go to the movies much. If you've seen one you've seen them all.
Thank you.

Oh, no offense. Movies are entertaining enough for the masses but the personalities on the screen just don't impress me. I mean they don't talk, they don't act, the just make a lot of dumb show. Well, you know
[demonstrates]
like that.
You mean like what I do?
Well, yes!
You keep away from me! Just because you're a big movie star, wild parties, swimming pools, you expect every girl to fall in a dead faint at your feet. Well, don't you touch me!

[chanting]
Fear not, sweet lady! I will not molest you. I am but a humble jester, and you? You are to far above me!
[he gets out of the car and closes the door on his coat tails]
Farewell, Ethel Barrymore! I must tear myself from your side!
[Don tears his coat. Kathy guffaws as Don walks away]
You have to show a movie at a party. It's a Hollywood law.
You mean it's going to say on the screen that I don't talk and sing for myself?
Are you doing anything tonight, Miss Lamont?
[she shakes her head "no"]
Well's that's funny - *I'm* busy.
[after Cosmo gives a good idea]
Cosmo, remind me to give you a raise.
[turns around]
Oh, R.F.
Yes?
Give me a raise.
[after picture is shown where Kathy is singing for Lina]
Lina, you were fabulous. You sang as good as Kathy Selden.

[after a take]
We're really rolling, Mr. Simpson.
Well, you can stop rolling at once.
What?
Don, Lina.
Ok, everybody save it!
Save it? Tell them to go home. We're shutting down for a few weeks.
What?
Well, don't just stand there. Tell them!
Everybody go until further notice! What is it?

[singing]
Gotta dance!

[singing]
Gotta dance! Gotta Dance! / Broadway Rhythm, it's got me, everybody dance!

[after seeing the film screw-up]
The sound, its out of synchronization!

[irritated]
Well tell them to fix it!

[while getting up]
Yes sir, fix it!
Did somebody get paid for writing that dialog?
What's the matter with that girl? Can't she take a gentle hint?
Well haven't ya heard? She's irresistible. She told me so herself.
I've got no fame, I've got no glory, I've got no big mansions, I've got no money! But I've got - what have I got?
I don't know, what have you got?
I gotta get out of here.
Where'd Miss Selden go?
She just grabbed her things and bolted. Anything I can do?
Sorry, I don't have time to find out.

[about Lina]
She's so refined. I think I'll kill myself.

[to Kathy, after she jumps out of the cake]
Well, if it isn't Ethel Barrymore.
Hello! This is a demonstration of a talking picture. Notice, it is a picture of me and I am talking. Note how my lips and the sound issuing from them are synchronized together in perfect unison.
Now listen, R.F., the owner of the Coconut Grove may do what Lina tells him to, but you're the head of this studio.
That's right, I'm the head of this studio. She's hired! But don't let Lina know she's on the lot.

[singing]
That's the Broadway Melody!
Lina, did you send this stuff out?
I gave an exclusive story to every paper in town.
I do hope you're going to favor us with something special tonight.
Please!
Say, Hamlet's soliloquy, or the balcony scene from "Romeo and Juliet."
Mr. Lockwood!
Don't be shy. You'd make about the prettiest Juliet I've ever seen. Really.
[Don's about to start shooting a new movie]
What's this one about?
It's a French revolution story...
Don't tell me. You're a French aristocrat, she's a simple girl of the people, and she won't even give you a tumbrel. Hah!
The new Don Lockwood. He yodels, he jumps around to music.
The only problem is once they release this movie, no-one's gonna want to see me jump off the Woolworth building into a damp rag.

[singing]
All I do is dream of you the whole night through; with the dawn I still go on, dreaming of you. You're every thought, you're everything, you're every song I ever sing; summer, winter, autumn and spring. And were there more than twenty four hours a day; they'd be spent in sweet content dreaming away; when skies are grey, when skies are blue; morning, noon and night time too; all I do the whole day through is dream of you.
Ladies and gentlemen, when you look at this gorgeous couple, it's no wonder they're a household name all over the world like... bacon and eggs. Lockwood and Lamont!
What's your name?
Don Lockwood sir, but the fellas all call me Donald.
Wise guy, eh? All right, get this guy into Bert's suit! And remember Lockwood, you might be trading that fiddle in for a harp!

[sings cheerfully]
Here we are! Sunset and Camden!
[first lines]

[broadcasting on radio]
This is Dora Bailey, ladies and gentlemen, talking to you from the front of the Chinese Theater in Hollywood. What a night, ladies and gentlemen, what a night! Every star in Hollywood's heaven is here to make Monumental Pictures' premiere of "The Royal Rascal" the outstanding event of 1927! Everyone is breathlessly awaiting the arrival of Lina Lamont and Don Lockwood!

[to the press]
They sent me to the finest schools, including dancing schools. That's where I first met Cosmo. And with him I used to perform for all of Mom and Dad's society friends.

[the lead-in to Don's "Singin' In the Rain" number]
This California dew's a little heavier than usual tonight.
Oh really? From where I stand, the sun is shining all over the place...
